<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Yosemite_National_Park skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Yosemite National Park</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
</p>
<div class="dablink">"Yosemite" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Yosemite (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_protected_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox protected area (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox protected area</a>
</p><p><b>Yosemite National Park</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a>) is a <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">United States National Park</a> spanning eastern portions of <a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_County,_California" title="Tuolumne County, California">Tuolumne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariposa_County,_California" title="Mariposa County, California">Mariposa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madera_County,_California" title="Madera County, California">Madera</a> counties in the central eastern portion of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. state (page does not exist)">U.S. state</a> of <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>. The park, which is managed by the <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a>, covers an area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><sup id="cite_ref-area_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-area-1">[1]</a></sup> and reaches across the western slopes of the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_(U.S.)" title="Sierra Nevada (U.S.)">Sierra Nevada</a> mountain chain.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> Over 3.7 million people visit Yosemite each year:<sup id="cite_ref-visits_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-visits-3">[3]</a></sup> most spend their time in the seven square miles (18&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) of <a href="/wiki/Yosemite_Valley" title="Yosemite Valley">Yosemite Valley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-naturehistory_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naturehistory-4">[4]</a></sup> Designated a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> in 1984, Yosemite is internationally recognized for its spectacular <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a> cliffs, <a href="/wiki/Waterfall" title="Waterfall">waterfalls</a>, clear <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stream (page does not exist)">streams</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giant_Sequoia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giant Sequoia (page does not exist)">Giant Sequoia</a> groves, and <a href="/wiki/Biological_diversity" title="Biological diversity" class="mw-redirect">biological diversity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-naturehistory_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naturehistory-4">[4]</a></sup> Almost 95% of the park is designated <a href="/wiki/Wilderness_area" title="Wilderness area">wilderness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>  Yosemite was central to the development of the national park idea. First, <a href="/wiki/Galen_Clark" title="Galen Clark">Galen Clark</a> and others lobbied to protect Yosemite Valley from development, ultimately leading to President <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a>'s signing the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_Grant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite Grant (page does not exist)">Yosemite Grant</a> in 1864. Later, <a href="/wiki/John_Muir" title="John Muir">John Muir</a> led a successful movement to establish a larger national park encompassing not just the valley, but surrounding mountains and forests as well - paving the way for the United States national park system.<sup id="cite_ref-historyculture_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-historyculture-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Yosemite is one of the largest and least fragmented <a href="/w/index.php?title=Habitat_(ecology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Habitat (ecology) (page does not exist)">habitat</a> blocks in the Sierra Nevada, and the park supports a diversity of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant (page does not exist)">plants</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal (page does not exist)">animals</a>. The park has an elevation range from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and contains five major <a href="/wiki/Life_zone" title="Life zone">vegetation zones</a>: <a href="/wiki/Chaparral" title="Chaparral">chaparral</a>/<a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">oak</a> woodland, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sierra_Nevada_lower_montane_forest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sierra Nevada lower montane forest (page does not exist)">lower montane forest</a>, upper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Montane_forest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Montane forest (page does not exist)">montane forest</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sierra_Nevada_subalpine_zone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sierra Nevada subalpine zone (page does not exist)">subalpine zone</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alpine_tundra" title="Alpine tundra">alpine</a>. Of California's 7,000 plant species, about 50% occur in the Sierra Nevada and more than 20% within Yosemite. There is suitable <a href="/wiki/Habitat" title="Habitat">habitat</a> or documentation for more than 160 rare plants in the park, with rare local <a href="/wiki/Geology" title="Geology">geologic</a> formations and unique <a href="/wiki/Soil" title="Soil">soils</a> characterizing the restricted ranges many of these plants occupy.<sup id="cite_ref-naturehistory_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naturehistory-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_the_Yosemite_area" title="Geology of the Yosemite area">geology of the Yosemite area</a> is characterized by granitic rocks and remnants of older rock. About 10 million years ago, the Sierra Nevada was uplifted and then tilted to form its relatively gentle western slopes and the more dramatic eastern slopes. The uplift increased the steepness of stream and river beds, resulting in formation of deep, narrow <a href="/wiki/Canyon" title="Canyon">canyons</a>. About 1 million years ago, <a href="/wiki/Snow" title="Snow">snow</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ice" title="Ice">ice</a> accumulated, forming <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">glaciers</a> at the higher <a href="/wiki/Alpine_tundra" title="Alpine tundra">alpine meadows</a> that moved down the river valleys. Ice thickness in Yosemite Valley may have reached <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> during the early glacial episode. The downslope movement of the ice masses cut and sculpted the U-shaped valley that attracts so many visitors to its scenic vistas today.<sup id="cite_ref-naturehistory_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naturehistory-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ahwahneechee_and_the_Mariposa_Wars">Ahwahneechee and the Mariposa Wars</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a> 
</p><p>As revealed by archeological finds, the Yosemite Valley has been inhabited for nearly 3000 years. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paiute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paiute (page does not exist)">Paiute</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Valley_and_Sierra_Miwok&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Valley and Sierra Miwok (page does not exist)">Sierra Miwok</a> peoples lived in the area long before the first explorations by American settlers into the region. A band of Paiute called the <i><a href="/wiki/Ahwahneechee" title="Ahwahneechee" class="mw-redirect">Ahwahneechee</a></i> were living in the <a href="/wiki/Yosemite_Valley" title="Yosemite Valley">Yosemite Valley</a> when the first known group of European Americans entered it.<sup id="cite_ref-Bunnell17_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bunnell17-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/California_Gold_Rush" title="California Gold Rush">California Gold Rush</a> in the mid-19th century dramatically increased travel by European-Americans in the area, causing competition for resources between the regional Paiute and Miwok and the miners and hangers on. In 1851 as part of the Mariposa Wars intended to suppress Native American resistance, <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">United States Army</a> Major <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jim_Savage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jim Savage (page does not exist)">Jim Savage</a> led the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mariposa_Battalion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mariposa Battalion (page does not exist)">Mariposa Battalion</a> into the west end of Yosemite Valley. He was pursuing forces of around 200 Ahwahneechee led by <a href="/wiki/Chief_Tenaya" title="Chief Tenaya">Chief Tenaya</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP326_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP326-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>Accounts from this battalion were the first well-documented reports of ethnic Europeans entering Yosemite Valley. Attached to Savage's unit was Dr. <a href="/wiki/Lafayette_Bunnell" title="Lafayette Bunnell">Lafayette Bunnell</a>, the company <a href="/wiki/Physician" title="Physician">physician</a>, who later wrote about his awestruck impressions of the valley in <i>The Discovery of the Yosemite</i>. Bunnell is credited with naming Yosemite Valley, based on his interviews with Chief Tenaya. Bunnell wrote that Chief Tenaya was the founder of the <a href="/wiki/Paiute_people" title="Paiute people">Pai-Ute Colony of Ah-wah-nee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bunnell17_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bunnell17-7">[7]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Miwok&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Miwok (page does not exist)">Miwok</a>, a neighboring tribe, and most white settlers considered the Ahwahneechee to be especially violent because of their frequent territorial disputes. The Miwok term for the Pai-Ute band was <i>yohhe'meti,</i> meaning "they are killers".<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> Correspondence and articles written by members of the battalion helped to popularize the natural wonders of the Yosemite Valley and the surrounding area.
</p><p>Chief Tenaya and his Ahwahneechee were eventually captured and their village burned; they were removed to a <a href="/wiki/Indian_reservation" title="Indian reservation">reservation</a> near <a href="/wiki/Fresno,_California" title="Fresno, California">Fresno, California</a>. The chief and some others were later allowed to return to Yosemite Valley. In the spring of 1852 they attacked a group of eight gold <a href="/wiki/Mining" title="Mining">miners</a>, and then moved east to flee law enforcement. <sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer46_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer46-11">[11]</a></sup> Near <a href="/wiki/Mono_Lake" title="Mono Lake">Mono Lake</a>, they took refuge with the nearby <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mono_tribe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mono tribe (page does not exist)">Mono tribe</a> of Paiute. They stole horses from their hosts and moved away, but the Mono Paiutes tracked down and killed many of the Ahwahneechee, including Chief Tenaya. The Mono Paiute took the survivors as captives back to Mono Lake and absorbed them into the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mono_Lake_Paiute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mono Lake Paiute (page does not exist)">Mono Lake Paiute</a> tribe. 
</p><p>A reconstructed "Indian Village of Ahwahnee" has been erected behind the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite Museum (page does not exist)">Yosemite Museum</a>, located next to the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vernal_Falls,_Yosemite,_by_Thomas_Hill,_1889.jpg" title="File:Vernal Falls, Yosemite, by Thomas Hill, 1889.jpg">File:Vernal Falls, Yosemite, by Thomas Hill, 1889.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Vernal Falls</i>, Yosemite (1889) by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Hill_(painter)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Hill (painter) (page does not exist)">Thomas Hill</a>, who painted many images of the region</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_tourists">Early tourists</span></h3>
<p>In 1855, entrepreneur <a href="/wiki/James_Mason_Hutchings" title="James Mason Hutchings">James Mason Hutchings</a>, artist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Ayres_(artist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Ayres (artist) (page does not exist)">Thomas Ayres</a> and two others were the first to tour the area.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP326_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP326-8">[8]</a></sup> Hutchings and Ayres were responsible for much of the earliest publicity about Yosemite, writing articles and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hutchings%27_Illustrated_California_Magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hutchings' Illustrated California Magazine (page does not exist)">special magazine issues about the Valley</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Ayres' style in art was highly detailed with exaggerated angularity. His works and written accounts were distributed nationally, and an art exhibition of his drawings was held in New York City. Hutchings' publicity efforts between 1855 and 1860 led to an increase in tourism to Yosemite.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Wawona,_California" title="Wawona, California">Wawona</a> was an Indian encampment in what is now the southwestern part of the park. Settler <a href="/wiki/Galen_Clark" title="Galen Clark">Galen Clark</a> discovered the <a href="/wiki/Mariposa_Grove" title="Mariposa Grove">Mariposa Grove</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giant_Sequoia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giant Sequoia (page does not exist)">Giant Sequoia</a> in Wawona in 1857. He had simple lodgings built, and roads to the area. In 1879, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wawona_Hotel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wawona Hotel (page does not exist)">Wawona Hotel</a> was built to serve tourists visiting Mariposa Grove. As tourism increased, so did the number of trails and hotels developed by people intending to build on the trade.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wawona_Tree&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wawona Tree (page does not exist)">Wawona Tree</a>, also known as the Tunnel Tree, was a famous giant sequoia that stood in the Mariposa Grove. It was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> tall, and was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in circumference. When a carriage-wide tunnel was cut through the tree in 1881, it became even more popular as a tourist photo attraction. Everything from horse-drawn carriages in the late 19th century, to automobiles in the first part of the 20th century, traveled the road which passed through that tree. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wawona_Tree&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wawona Tree (page does not exist)">Wawona Tree</a> fell in 1969 under a heavy load of snow. It was estimated to have been 2,300 years old.
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a> 
Yosemite's first concession was established in 1884 when John Degnan and his wife established a bakery and store.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 1916, the National Park Service granted a 20-year concession to the Desmond Park Service Company. It bought out or built hotels, stores, camps, a dairy, a garage, and other park services.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Desmond changed its name to the Yosemite National Park Company in December 1917 and was reorganized in 1920.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The Curry Company had been started in 1899 by David and Jennie Curry to provide concessions in the park. They also founded Camp Curry, now known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Curry_Village&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Curry Village (page does not exist)">Curry Village</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The Currys lobbied reluctant park supervisors to allow expansion of concession operations and development in the area.
</p><p>Administrators in the National Park Service felt that limiting the number of concessionaires in each national park would be more financially sound. The Curry Company and its rival, the Yosemite National Park Company, were forced to merge in 1925 to form the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_Park_%26_Curry_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite Park &amp; Curry Company (page does not exist)">Yosemite Park &amp; Curry Company</a> (YP&amp;CC).<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The company built the <a href="/wiki/Ahwahnee_Hotel" title="Ahwahnee Hotel">Ahwahnee Hotel</a> in 1927.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Yosemite_Grant">Yosemite Grant</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Rail_and_Stage_Routes_to_the_Yosemite_1885.jpg" title="File:Map of Rail and Stage Routes to the Yosemite 1885.jpg">File:Map of Rail and Stage Routes to the Yosemite 1885.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of rail and stage routes to the Yosemite in 1885.</div></div></div>
<p>Concerned by the effects of commercial interests, prominent citizens including <a href="/wiki/Galen_Clark" title="Galen Clark">Galen Clark</a> and Senator <a href="/wiki/John_Conness" title="John Conness">John Conness</a> advocated for protection of the area. A park bill was prepared with the assistance of the <a href="/wiki/General_Land_Office" title="General Land Office">General Land Office</a> in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Interior" title="United States Department of the Interior">Interior Department</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> The bill passed both houses of the <a href="/wiki/38th_United_States_Congress" title="38th United States Congress">38th United States Congress</a>, and was signed by <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> on June 30, 1864, creating the Yosemite Grant.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer48_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer48-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> This is the first instance of park land being set aside specifically for preservation and public use by action of the U.S. federal government, and set a precedent for the 1872 creation of <a href="/wiki/Yellowstone_National_Park" title="Yellowstone National Park">Yellowstone</a> as the first <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national park</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-historyculture_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-historyculture-6">[6]</a></sup> Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Grove were ceded to <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a> as a <a href="/wiki/State_park" title="State park">state park</a>, and a board of commissioners was proclaimed two years later.
</p><p>Galen Clark was appointed by the commission as the Grant's first guardian, but neither Clark nor the commissioners had the authority to evict <a href="/w/index.php?title=Homestead_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homestead Act (page does not exist)">homesteaders</a> (which included Hutchings).<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer48_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer48-14">[14]</a></sup> The issue was not settled until 1872 when the homesteader land holdings were invalidated by the U.S. Supreme Court.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> Clark and the reigning commissioners were ousted in 1880, this dispute also reaching the Supreme Court in 1880.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> The two Supreme Court decisions affecting management of the Yosemite Grant are considered important precedents in land management law.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Hutchings became the new park guardian.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer49_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer49-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>Access to the park by tourists improved in the early years of the park, and conditions in the Valley were made more hospitable. Tourism significantly increased after the <a href="/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad" title="First Transcontinental Railroad">First Transcontinental Railroad</a> was completed in 1869, but the long horseback ride to reach the area was a deterrent.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer48_14-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer48-14">[14]</a></sup> Three <a href="/wiki/Stagecoach" title="Stagecoach">stagecoach</a> roads were built in the mid-1870s to provide better access for the growing number of visitors to Yosemite Valley.
</p><p>Scottish-born <a href="/w/index.php?title=Naturalist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Naturalist (page does not exist)">naturalist</a> <a href="/wiki/John_Muir" title="John Muir">John Muir</a> wrote articles popularizing the area and increasing scientific interest in it. Muir was one of the first to theorize that the major landforms in Yosemite Valley were created by large alpine <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">glaciers</a>, bucking established scientists such as <a href="/wiki/Josiah_Whitney" title="Josiah Whitney">Josiah Whitney</a>, who regarded Muir as an amateur.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer49_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer49-19">[19]</a></sup> Muir wrote scientific papers on the area's biology. Landscape architect <a href="/wiki/Frederick_Law_Olmsted" title="Frederick Law Olmsted">Frederick Law Olmsted</a> emphasized the importance of conservation of Yosemite Valley.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Increased_protection_efforts">Increased protection efforts</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>Overgrazing of <a href="/wiki/Meadow" title="Meadow">meadows</a> (especially by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sheep&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sheep (page does not exist)">sheep</a>), <a href="/wiki/Logging" title="Logging">logging</a> of Giant Sequoia, and other damage caused Muir to become an advocate for further protection. Muir convinced prominent guests of the importance of putting the area under federal protection; one such guest was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Underwood_Johnson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Underwood Johnson (page does not exist)">Robert Underwood Johnson</a>, editor of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Century_Magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Century Magazine (page does not exist)">Century Magazine</a></i>. Muir and Johnson lobbied Congress for the Act that created Yosemite National Park on October 1, 1890.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer50_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer50-20">[20]</a></sup> The State of California, however, retained control of Yosemite Valley and Mariposa Grove. Muir also helped persuade local officials to virtually eliminate grazing from the Yosemite high country.
</p><p>The newly created national park came under the jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">United States Army</a>'s Troop I of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=4th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="4th Cavalry Regiment (United States) (page does not exist)">4th Cavalry</a> on May 19, 1891, which set up camp in Wawona with Captain <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abram_Wood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abram Wood (page does not exist)">Abram Epperson Wood</a> as acting superintendent.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer50_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer50-20">[20]</a></sup> By the late 1890s, sheep grazing was no longer a problem, and the Army made many other improvements. The cavalry could not intervene to ease the worsening condition of Yosemite Valley and Mariposa Grove. The cavalry left another legacy in the park, the ranger hat. From 1899 to 1913, cavalry regiments of the Western Department, including the all Black <a href="/w/index.php?title=9th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="9th Cavalry Regiment (United States) (page does not exist)">9th Cavalry</a> (known as the "Buffalo Soldiers") and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1st_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1st Cavalry Regiment (United States) (page does not exist)">1st Cavalry</a>, stationed two troops at Yosemite and brought with them the trooper's campaign hat with its distinctive Montana Peak we recognize today as the "ranger hat." This peak had been formed into the trooper's stetson by veterans of the 1898 Spanish American War to better shed tropical rain. 
</p><p>Muir and his <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Club" title="Sierra Club">Sierra Club</a> continued to lobby the government and influential people for the creation of a unified Yosemite National Park. In May 1903, President <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> camped with Muir near <a href="/wiki/Glacier_Point" title="Glacier Point">Glacier Point</a> for three days. On that trip, Muir convinced Roosevelt to take control of Yosemite Valley and Mariposa Grove away from California and return it to the federal government. In 1906, Roosevelt signed a bill that did precisely that.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="U.S._National_Park_Service">U.S. National Park Service</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:O%27Shaughnessy_Dam.jpg" title="File:O'Shaughnessy Dam.jpg">File:O'Shaughnessy Dam.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">O'Shaughnessy Dam in <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Valley" title="Hetch Hetchy Valley" class="mw-redirect">Hetch Hetchy Valley</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a> was formed in 1916, and Yosemite was transferred to that agency's jurisdiction. Tuolumne Meadows Lodge, <a href="/wiki/Tioga_Pass_Road" title="Tioga Pass Road" class="mw-redirect">Tioga Pass Road</a>, and campgrounds at Tenaya and Merced lakes were also completed in 1916.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer52_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer52-21">[21]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Automobile&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Automobile (page does not exist)">Automobiles</a> started to enter the park in ever-increasing numbers following the construction of all-weather highways to the park. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite Museum (page does not exist)">Yosemite Museum</a> was founded in 1926 through the efforts of <a href="/wiki/Ansel_Franklin_Hall" title="Ansel Franklin Hall">Ansel Franklin Hall</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In 1903, a dam in the northern portion of the park was proposed. Located in the <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Valley" title="Hetch Hetchy Valley" class="mw-redirect">Hetch Hetchy Valley</a>, its purpose was to provide water and <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power" title="Hydroelectric power" class="mw-redirect">hydroelectric power</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=San_Francisco,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San Francisco, California (page does not exist)">San Francisco</a>. Muir and the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Club" title="Sierra Club">Sierra Club</a> opposed the project, while others, including <a href="/wiki/Gifford_Pinchot" title="Gifford Pinchot">Gifford Pinchot</a>, supported it.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> In 1913, the U.S. Congress authorized the <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy" title="Hetch Hetchy">O'Shaughnessy Dam</a> through passage of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raker_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raker Act (page does not exist)">Raker Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Schaffer51_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaffer51-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the late 1920s, in an attempt that would be impossible to make today, a <a href="/wiki/Bids_for_Olympic_Games#All-time_Winter_Olympics_bids" title="Bids for Olympic Games">bid</a> for Yosemite for the <a href="/wiki/1932_Winter_Olympics" title="1932 Winter Olympics">1932 Winter Olympics</a> was put forward.<sup id="cite_ref-olympics1932_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-olympics1932-24">[24]</a></sup>  (Ultimately, <a href="/wiki/Lake_Placid,_New_York" title="Lake Placid, New York">Lake Placid, New York</a>, hosted.)<sup id="cite_ref-olympics1932_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-olympics1932-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Panoramic_Overview_from_Glacier_Point_over_Yosemite_Valley_2013_Alternative.jpg" title="File:Panoramic Overview from Glacier Point over Yosemite Valley 2013 Alternative.jpg">File:Panoramic Overview from Glacier Point over Yosemite Valley 2013 Alternative.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Panoramic view from <a href="/wiki/Glacier_Point" title="Glacier Point">Glacier Point</a> over Yosemite Valley, 2013</div></div></div>
<p>More recently, preservationists persuaded Congress to designate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, or about 89% of the park, as the <b>Yosemite Wilderness</b>—a highly protected <a href="/wiki/Wilderness_area" title="Wilderness area">wilderness area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> The Park Service has reduced artificial inducements to visit the park, such as the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_Firefall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite Firefall (page does not exist)">Firefall</a></i>, in which red-hot embers were pushed off a cliff near <a href="/wiki/Glacier_Point" title="Glacier Point">Glacier Point</a> at night. <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">Traffic congestion</a> in Yosemite Valley during the summer months has become a concern. Two electric buses commenced service in September 1995. The buses are quiet and do not emit pollutants. Eventually, all the buses in Yosemite will be electric.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=1996_Yosemite_Valley_Landslide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1996 Yosemite Valley Landslide (page does not exist)">1996 Yosemite Valley Landslide</a> killed a hiker and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=January_1997_Merced_River_flood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="January 1997 Merced River flood (page does not exist)">January 1997 Merced River flood</a> damaged many roads and several campgrounds.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yosemite_National_Park_Map.png" title="File:Yosemite National Park Map.png">File:Yosemite National Park Map.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Yosemite National Park Map</div></div></div>
<p>Yosemite National Park is located in the central Sierra Nevada of California. Three wilderness areas are adjacent to Yosemite: the <a href="/wiki/Ansel_Adams_Wilderness" title="Ansel Adams Wilderness">Ansel Adams Wilderness</a> to the southeast, the <a href="/wiki/Hoover_Wilderness" title="Hoover Wilderness">Hoover Wilderness</a> to the northeast, and the <a href="/wiki/Emigrant_Wilderness" title="Emigrant Wilderness">Emigrant Wilderness</a> to the north.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> park is roughly the size of the U.S. state of <a href="/wiki/Rhode_Island" title="Rhode Island">Rhode Island</a> and contains thousands of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lake (page does not exist)">lakes</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pond&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pond (page does not exist)">ponds</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of streams, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of <a href="/wiki/Hiking" title="Hiking">hiking</a> trails, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of roads.<sup id="cite_ref-nature_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nature-27">[27]</a></sup> Two federally designated <a href="/wiki/Wild_and_Scenic_River" title="Wild and Scenic River" class="mw-redirect">Wild and Scenic Rivers</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Merced_River" title="Merced River">Merced</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_River" title="Tuolumne River">Tuolumne</a>, begin within Yosemite's borders and flow westward through the Sierra foothills, into the <a href="/w/index.php?title=California_Central_Valley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California Central Valley (page does not exist)">Central Valley of California</a>. Annual park visitation exceeds 3.5&#160;million, with most visitor use concentrated in the seven-square-mile (18&#160;km<sup>2</sup>) area of <a href="/wiki/Yosemite_Valley" title="Yosemite Valley">Yosemite Valley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nature_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nature-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rocks_and_erosion">Rocks and erosion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yosemite_El_Capitan.jpg" title="File:Yosemite El Capitan.jpg">File:Yosemite El Capitan.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/El_Capitan" title="El Capitan">El Capitan</a></div></div></div>
<p>Almost all of the <a href="/wiki/Landforms" title="Landforms" class="mw-redirect">landforms</a> in the Yosemite area are cut from the <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granitic</a> rock of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sierra_Nevada_Batholith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sierra Nevada Batholith (page does not exist)">Sierra Nevada Batholith</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Batholith" title="Batholith">batholith</a> is a large mass of intrusive <a href="/w/index.php?title=Igneous_rock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Igneous rock (page does not exist)">igneous rock</a> that formed deep below the surface).<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP329_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP329-28">[28]</a></sup> About 5% of the park's landforms (mostly in its eastern margin near <a href="/wiki/Mount_Dana" title="Mount Dana">Mount Dana</a>) are <a href="/wiki/Metamorphic_rock" title="Metamorphic rock">metamorphosed</a> <a href="/wiki/Volcanic_rock" title="Volcanic rock">volcanic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sedimentary_rock" title="Sedimentary rock">sedimentary rocks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-landforms_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-landforms-29">[29]</a></sup> These rocks are called <i>roof pendants</i> because they were once the roof of the underlying granitic rock.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">Erosion</a> acting upon different types of uplift-created joint and fracture systems is responsible for creating the valleys, canyons, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dome_(geology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dome (geology) (page does not exist)">domes</a>, and other features we see today. These joints and fracture systems do not move, and are therefore not <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">faults</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP331_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP331-31">[31]</a></sup> Spacing between joints is controlled by the amount of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Silica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Silica (page does not exist)">silica</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Granodiorite" title="Granodiorite">granodiorite</a> rocks; more silica tends to create a more resistant rock, resulting in larger spaces between joints and fractures.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyUSP220_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyUSP220-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pillars and columns, such as Washington Column and Lost Arrow, are created by cross joints. <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">Erosion</a> acting on master joints is responsible for creating valleys and later canyons.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyUSP220_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyUSP220-32">[32]</a></sup> The single most erosive force over the last few million years has been large alpine <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">glaciers</a>, which have turned the previously V-shaped river-cut valleys into U-shaped glacial-cut canyons (such as <a href="/wiki/Yosemite_Valley" title="Yosemite Valley">Yosemite Valley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Valley" title="Hetch Hetchy Valley" class="mw-redirect">Hetch Hetchy Valley</a>). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Exfoliation_(geology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Exfoliation (geology) (page does not exist)">Exfoliation</a> (caused by the tendency of <a href="/wiki/Crystal" title="Crystal">crystals</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pluton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pluton (page does not exist)">plutonic</a> rocks to expand at the surface) acting on granitic rock with widely spaced joints is responsible for creating domes such as <a href="/wiki/Half_Dome" title="Half Dome">Half Dome</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Dome" title="North Dome">North Dome</a> and inset arches like Royal Arches.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP332_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP332-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_features">Popular features</span></h3>
<p>Yosemite Valley represents only one percent of the park area, but this is where most visitors arrive and stay. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wawona_Tunnel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wawona Tunnel (page does not exist)">Tunnel View</a> is the first view of the Valley for many visitors and is extensively photographed. <a href="/wiki/El_Capitan" title="El Capitan">El Capitan</a>, a prominent granite cliff that looms over Yosemite Valley, is one of the most popular <a href="/wiki/Rock_climbing" title="Rock climbing">rock climbing</a> destinations in the world because of its diverse range of climbing routes in addition to its year-round accessibility. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Granite_dome&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Granite dome (page does not exist)">Granite domes</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Sentinel_Dome" title="Sentinel Dome">Sentinel Dome</a> and <a href="/wiki/Half_Dome" title="Half Dome">Half Dome</a> rise <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, respectively, above the valley floor.
</p><p>The high country of Yosemite contains beautiful areas such as <a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_Meadows" title="Tuolumne Meadows">Tuolumne Meadows</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dana_Meadows" title="Dana Meadows">Dana Meadows</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Clark_Range_(California)" title="Clark Range (California)">Clark Range</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_Range" title="Cathedral Range">Cathedral Range</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuna_Crest_Granodiorite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuna Crest Granodiorite (page does not exist)">Kuna Crest</a>. The Sierra crest and the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Crest_Trail" title="Pacific Crest Trail">Pacific Crest Trail</a> run through Yosemite, with peaks of red <a href="/wiki/Metamorphic_rock" title="Metamorphic rock">metamorphic rock</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Mount_Dana" title="Mount Dana">Mount Dana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mount_Gibbs" title="Mount Gibbs">Mount Gibbs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a> peaks, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mount_Conness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mount Conness (page does not exist)">Mount Conness</a>. <a href="/wiki/Mount_Lyell_(California)" title="Mount Lyell (California)">Mount Lyell</a> is the highest point in the park, standing at 13,120&#160;ft.  The Lyell Glacier is the largest glacier in Yosemite National Park and is one of the few remaining in the Sierra Nevada today.
</p><p>The park has three groves of ancient <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giant_Sequoia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giant Sequoia (page does not exist)">Giant Sequoia</a> (<i>Sequoiadendron giganteum</i>) <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tree&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tree (page does not exist)">trees</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Mariposa_Grove" title="Mariposa Grove">Mariposa Grove</a> (200 trees), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tuolumne_Grove&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tuolumne Grove (page does not exist)">Tuolumne Grove</a> (25 trees), and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Merced_Grove&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Merced Grove (page does not exist)">Merced Grove</a> (20 trees).<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP340_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP340-34">[34]</a></sup> This species grows larger in volume than any other and is one of the tallest and longest-lived.<sup id="cite_ref-Kiver227_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kiver227-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_and_ice">Water and ice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_River" title="Tuolumne River">Tuolumne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Merced_River" title="Merced River">Merced River</a> systems originate along the crest of the <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_(U.S.)" title="Sierra Nevada (U.S.)">Sierra Nevada</a> in the park and have carved river canyons <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> deep. The Tuolumne River drains the entire northern portion of the park, an area of approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The Merced River begins in the park's southern peaks, primarily the <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_Range" title="Cathedral Range">Cathedral</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clark_Range_(California)" title="Clark Range (California)">Clark Ranges</a>, and drains an area of approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-water_overview_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-water_overview-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yosemite_USA.JPG" title="File:Yosemite USA.JPG">File:Yosemite USA.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=U-shaped_valley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U-shaped valley (page does not exist)">U-shaped valley</a> - Yosemite</div></div></div>
<p>Hydrologic processes, including <a href="/wiki/Glaciation" title="Glaciation" class="mw-redirect">glaciation</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flooding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flooding (page does not exist)">flooding</a>, and fluvial geomorphic response, have been fundamental in creating landforms in the park.<sup id="cite_ref-water_overview_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-water_overview-36">[36]</a></sup> The park also contains approximately 3,200 lakes (greater than 100 m²), two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reservoir_(water)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reservoir (water) (page does not exist)">reservoirs</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of streams, all of which help form these two large <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">watersheds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hydrology_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hydrology-37">[37]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wetland" title="Wetland">Wetlands</a> in Yosemite occur in valley bottoms throughout the park, and are often hydrologically linked to nearby lakes and rivers through seasonal flooding and groundwater movement. <a href="/wiki/Meadow" title="Meadow">Meadow</a> habitats, distributed at elevations from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in the park, are generally wetlands, as are the <a href="/wiki/Riparian" title="Riparian" class="mw-redirect">riparian</a> habitats found on the banks of Yosemite's numerous streams and rivers.<sup id="cite_ref-wetland_vegetation_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wetland_vegetation-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bridalveil_Fall_and_valley.JPG" title="File:Bridalveil Fall and valley.JPG">File:Bridalveil Fall and valley.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bridalveil_Fall_(Yosemite)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bridalveil Fall (Yosemite) (page does not exist)">Bridalveil Fall</a> flows from a U-shaped hanging valley that was created by a tributary glacier.</div></div></div>
<p>Yosemite is famous for its <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Yosemite_waterfalls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Yosemite waterfalls (page does not exist)">high concentration of waterfalls</a> in a small area. Numerous sheer drops, glacial steps and <a href="/wiki/Hanging_valley" title="Hanging valley" class="mw-redirect">hanging valleys</a> in the park provide many places for <a href="/wiki/Waterfall" title="Waterfall">waterfalls</a> to exist, especially during April, May, and June (the snowmelt season). Located in Yosemite Valley, the <a href="/wiki/Yosemite_Falls" title="Yosemite Falls">Yosemite Falls</a> is the highest in North America at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. Also in Yosemite Valley is the much lower volume <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ribbon_Fall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ribbon Fall (page does not exist)">Ribbon Falls</a>, which has the highest single vertical drop, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kiver227_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kiver227-35">[35]</a></sup> Perhaps the most prominent of the Yosemite Valley waterfalls is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bridalveil_Fall_(Yosemite)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bridalveil Fall (Yosemite) (page does not exist)">Bridalveil Fall</a>, which is the waterfall seen from the Tunnel View viewpoint at the east end of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wawona_Tunnel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wawona Tunnel (page does not exist)">Wawona Tunnel</a>. Wapama Falls in <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Valley" title="Hetch Hetchy Valley" class="mw-redirect">Hetch Hetchy Valley</a> is another notable waterfall. Hundreds of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ephemeral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ephemeral (page does not exist)">ephemeral</a> waterfalls also exist in the park.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vernal_Fall_08776.JPG" title="File:Vernal Fall 08776.JPG">File:Vernal Fall 08776.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Vernal_Fall" title="Vernal Fall">Vernal Fall</a></div></div></div>
<p>All <a href="/wiki/Glacier" title="Glacier">glaciers</a> in the park are relatively small glaciers that occupy areas that are in almost permanent shade, such as north- and northeast-facing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cirque_(landform)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cirque (landform) (page does not exist)">cirques</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lyell_Glacier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lyell Glacier (page does not exist)">Lyell Glacier</a> is the largest glacier in Yosemite (the Palisades Glaciers are the largest in the Sierra Nevada) and covers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyUSP228_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyUSP228-39">[39]</a></sup> None of the Yosemite glaciers are a remnant of the much, much larger <a href="/wiki/Ice_Age" title="Ice Age" class="mw-redirect">Ice Age</a> alpine glaciers responsible for sculpting the Yosemite landscape. Instead, they were formed during one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neoglacial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neoglacial (page does not exist)">neoglacial</a> episodes that have occurred since the thawing of the Ice Age (such as the <a href="/wiki/Little_Ice_Age" title="Little Ice Age">Little Ice Age</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP340_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP340-34">[34]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">Climate change</a> has reduced the number and size of glaciers around the world. Many Yosemite glaciers, including Merced Glacier, which was discovered by <a href="/wiki/John_Muir" title="John Muir">John Muir</a> in 1871 and bolstered his glacial origins theory of the Yosemite area, have disappeared and most of the others have lost up to 75% of their surface area.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyUSP228_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyUSP228-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:El_Capitan_at_fall.jpg" title="File:El Capitan at fall.jpg">File:El Capitan at fall.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Yosemite in <a href="/wiki/Autumn" title="Autumn">Autumn</a></div></div></div>
<p>Yosemite has a <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> <i>Csa</i>), meaning most precipitation falls during the mild winter, and the other seasons are nearly dry (less than 3% of precipitation falls during the long, hot summers).<sup id="cite_ref-Wuerthner8_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wuerthner8-40">[40]</a></sup> Because of <a href="/wiki/Orographic_lift" title="Orographic lift">orographic lift</a>, precipitation increases with elevation up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> where it slowly decreases to the crest. Precipitation amounts vary from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> elevation to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. Snow does not typically persist on the ground until November in the high country. It accumulates all winter and into March or early April.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mean daily temperatures range from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> at Tuolumne Meadows at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. At the Wawona Entrance (elevation <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>), mean daily temperature ranges from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. At the lower elevations below <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, temperatures are hotter; the mean daily high temperature at Yosemite Valley (elevation <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>) varies from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. At elevations above <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, the hot, dry summer temperatures are moderated by frequent summer <a href="/wiki/Thunderstorm" title="Thunderstorm">thunderstorms</a>, along with snow that can persist into July. The combination of dry <a href="/wiki/Vegetation" title="Vegetation">vegetation</a>, low relative <a href="/wiki/Humidity" title="Humidity">humidity</a>, and thunderstorms results in frequent <a href="/wiki/Lightning" title="Lightning">lightning</a>-caused <a href="/wiki/Wildfire" title="Wildfire">fires</a> as well.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the park headquarters, with an elevation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, January averages <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, while July averages <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, though in summer the nights are much cooler than the hot days.<sup id="cite_ref-NCDC2_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NCDC2-42">[42]</a></sup> There are an average of 39.5 days with highs of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> or higher and an average of 97.9 nights with freezing temperatures.<sup id="cite_ref-NCDC2_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NCDC2-42">[42]</a></sup> Freezing temperatures have been recorded in every month of the year. The record high temperature was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on July 20, 1915, while the record low temperature was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on January 2, 1924 and on January 21, 1937.<sup id="cite_ref-NCDC2_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NCDC2-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WRCC_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WRCC-43">[43]</a></sup> Average annual precipitation is nearly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, falling on 65 days. The wettest year was 1983 with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and the dryest year was 1976 with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WRCC_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WRCC-43">[43]</a></sup> The most precipitation in one month was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in December 1955 and the most in one day was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> on December 23, 1955.<sup id="cite_ref-WRCC_43-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WRCC-43">[43]</a></sup> Average annual snowfall is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The snowiest year was 1967 with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The most snow in one month was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in January 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-WRCC_43-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WRCC-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Weather_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Weather box (page does not exist)">Template:Weather box</a>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology">Geology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tectonic_and_volcanic_activity">Tectonic and volcanic activity</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Yosemite_National_Park.svg" title="File:Map of Yosemite National Park.svg">File:Map of Yosemite National Park.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Generalized geologic map of the Yosemite area (based on an <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Geological_Survey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Geological Survey (page does not exist)">USGS</a> image)</div></div></div>
<p>The area of the park was astride a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Passive_continental_margin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Passive continental margin (page does not exist)">passive continental margin</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Precambrian" title="Precambrian">Precambrian</a> and early <a href="/wiki/Paleozoic" title="Paleozoic">Paleozoic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP328_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP328-44">[44]</a></sup> Sediment was derived from continental sources and was deposited in shallow water. These rocks have since been <a href="/wiki/Metamorphic_rock" title="Metamorphic rock">metamorphosed</a>.
</p><p>Heat generated from the <a href="/wiki/Farallon_Plate" title="Farallon Plate">Farallon Plate</a> <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subducting</a> below the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate">North American Plate</a> led to the creation of an <a href="/wiki/Island_arc" title="Island arc">island arc</a> of volcanoes on the west coast of proto-North America between the late <a href="/wiki/Devonian" title="Devonian">Devonian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Permian" title="Permian">Permian</a> periods.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP328_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP328-44">[44]</a></sup> Later volcanism in the <a href="/wiki/Jurassic" title="Jurassic">Jurassic</a> intruded and covered these rocks in what may have been magmatic activity associated with the early stages of the creation of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sierra_Nevada_Batholith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sierra Nevada Batholith (page does not exist)">Sierra Nevada Batholith</a>. 95% of these rocks were eventually removed by uplifted-accelerated erosion.
</p><p>The first phase of regional <a href="/wiki/Intrusion_(geology)" title="Intrusion (geology)" class="mw-redirect">plutonism</a> started 210 million years ago in the late Triassic and continued throughout the Jurassic to about 150 million years before present (<a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">BP</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP329_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP329-28">[28]</a></sup> Around the same time, the <a href="/wiki/Nevadan_orogeny" title="Nevadan orogeny">Nevadan orogeny</a> built the Nevadan mountain range (also called the Ancestral Sierra Nevada) to a height of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. This was directly part of the creation of the Sierra Nevada Batholith, and the resulting rocks were mostly <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granitic</a> in composition and emplaced about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> below the surface.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP337_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP337-45">[45]</a></sup> The second major pluton emplacement phase lasted from about 120 million to 80 million years ago during the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP329_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP329-28">[28]</a></sup> This was part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sevier_orogeny&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sevier orogeny (page does not exist)">Sevier orogeny</a>.
</p><p>Starting 20 million years ago (in the <a href="/wiki/Cenozoic" title="Cenozoic">Cenozoic</a>) and lasting until 5 million years ago, a now-extinct extension of <a href="/wiki/Cascade_Range" title="Cascade Range">Cascade Range</a> <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcanoes</a> erupted, bringing large amounts of igneous material in the area. These igneous deposits blanketed the region north of the Yosemite region. Volcanic activity persisted past 5 million years <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">BP</a> east of the current park borders in the <a href="/wiki/Mono_Lake" title="Mono Lake">Mono Lake</a> and <a href="/wiki/Long_Valley_Caldera" title="Long Valley Caldera">Long Valley</a> areas.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Uplift_and_erosion">Uplift and erosion</span></h3>
<p>Starting 10 million years ago, vertical movement along the Sierra fault started to uplift the Sierra Nevada. Subsequent tilting of the Sierra block and the resulting accelerated uplift of the Sierra Nevada increased the <a href="/wiki/Gradient" title="Gradient">gradient</a> of western-flowing streams.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP339_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP339-46">[46]</a></sup> The streams consequently ran faster and thus cut their valleys more quickly. Additional uplift occurred when major faults developed to the east, especially the creation of <a href="/wiki/Owens_Valley" title="Owens Valley">Owens Valley</a> from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Basin_and_Range&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Basin and Range (page does not exist)">Basin and Range</a>-associated extensional forces. Uplift of the Sierra accelerated again about two million years ago during the <a href="/wiki/Pleistocene" title="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Half_Dome_from_Glacier_Point,_Yosemite_NP_-_Diliff.jpg" title="File:Half Dome from Glacier Point, Yosemite NP - Diliff.jpg">File:Half Dome from Glacier Point, Yosemite NP - Diliff.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Exfoliation_(geology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Exfoliation (geology) (page does not exist)">Exfoliation</a> joints have modified the near-surface portions of massive granitic rocks in the park, helping create the many spectacular domes, including Half Dome shown here.</div></div></div>
<p>The uplifting and increased erosion exposed granitic rocks in the area to surface pressures, resulting in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Exfoliation_(geology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Exfoliation (geology) (page does not exist)">exfoliation</a> (responsible for the rounded shape of the many domes in the park) and mass wasting following the numerous fracture joint planes (cracks; especially vertical ones) in the now solidified plutons.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP332_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP332-33">[33]</a></sup> Pleistocene glaciers further accelerated this process and the larger ones transported the resulting <a href="/wiki/Scree" title="Scree">talus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Till" title="Till">till</a> from valley floors.
</p><p>Numerous vertical joint planes controlled where and how fast erosion took place. Most of these long, linear and very deep cracks trend northeast or northwest and form parallel, often regularly spaced sets. They were created by uplift-associated pressure release and by the unloading of overlying rock via erosion.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sculpting_by_glaciers">Sculpting by glaciers</span></h3>
<p>A series of <a href="/wiki/Glaciation" title="Glaciation" class="mw-redirect">glaciations</a> further modified the region starting about 2 to 3 million years ago and ending sometime around 10,000 <a href="/wiki/Before_Present" title="Before Present">BP</a>. At least four major glaciations have occurred in the Sierra Nevada, locally called the Sherwin (also called the pre-Tahoe), Tahoe, Tenaya, and Tioga.<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP339_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP339-46">[46]</a></sup> The Sherwin glaciers were the largest, filling Yosemite and other valleys, while later stages produced much smaller glaciers. A Sherwin-age glacier was almost surely responsible for the major excavation and shaping of Yosemite Valley and other canyons in the area.
</p><p>Glacial systems reached depths of up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and left their marks in the Yosemite area. The longest glacier in the Yosemite area ran down the Grand Canyon of the <a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_River" title="Tuolumne River">Tuolumne River</a> for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, passing well beyond <a href="/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Valley" title="Hetch Hetchy Valley" class="mw-redirect">Hetch Hetchy Valley</a>. Merced Glacier flowed out of Yosemite Valley and into the <a href="/wiki/Merced_River" title="Merced River">Merced River Gorge</a>. Lee Vining Glacier carved Lee Vining Canyon and emptied into Lake Russel (the much-enlarged ice age version of <a href="/wiki/Mono_Lake" title="Mono Lake">Mono Lake</a>). Only the highest peaks, such as <a href="/wiki/Mount_Dana" title="Mount Dana">Mount Dana</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mount_Conness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mount Conness (page does not exist)">Mount Conness</a>, were not covered by glaciers. Retreating glaciers often left recessional <a href="/wiki/Moraine" title="Moraine">moraines</a> that impounded lakes such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long Lake Yosemite (a shallow lake that periodically covered much of the floor of Yosemite Valley).<sup id="cite_ref-GeologyNP333_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GeologyNP333-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Glacier_Point_at_Sunset,_Yosemite_NP,_CA,_US_-_Diliff.jpg" title="File:Glacier Point at Sunset, Yosemite NP, CA, US - Diliff.jpg">File:Glacier Point at Sunset, Yosemite NP, CA, US - Diliff.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">View from <a href="/wiki/Glacier_Point" title="Glacier Point">Glacier Point</a> looking towards <a href="/wiki/Half_Dome" title="Half Dome">Half Dome</a></div></div></div></div>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biology">Biology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Habitats">Habitats</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mule_deer_in_Yosemite_Valley.jpg" title="File:Mule deer in Yosemite Valley.jpg">File:Mule deer in Yosemite Valley.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mule_Deer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mule Deer (page does not exist)">Mule Deer</a> in Yosemite Valley</div></div></div>
<p>With its scrubby sun-baked <a href="/wiki/Chaparral" title="Chaparral">chaparral</a>, stately groves of pine, fir, and sequoia, and expanses of alpine woodlands and meadows, Yosemite National Park preserves a Sierra Nevada landscape as it prevailed before Euro-American settlement.<sup id="cite_ref-snepLateSuccessional_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-snepLateSuccessional-48">[48]</a></sup> In contrast to surrounding lands, which have been significantly altered by logging, the park still contains some <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of <a href="/wiki/Old-growth_forest" title="Old-growth forest">old-growth forest</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1993OldGrowthEstimates_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1993OldGrowthEstimates-49">[49]</a></sup> Taken together, the park's varied <a href="/w/index.php?title=Habitat_(ecology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Habitat (ecology) (page does not exist)">habitats</a> support over 250 species of <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">vertebrates</a>, which include fish, <a href="/wiki/Amphibia" title="Amphibia" class="mw-redirect">amphibians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptiles</a>, birds, and mammals.<sup id="cite_ref-wildlife_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wildlife-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CaliforniaTree.jpg" title="File:CaliforniaTree.jpg">File:CaliforniaTree.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">California tree in Yosemite Valley</div></div></div>
<p>Along much of Yosemite's western boundary, habitats are dominated by mixed <a href="/wiki/Coniferous_forest" title="Coniferous forest" class="mw-redirect">coniferous forests</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ponderosa_Pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ponderosa Pine (page does not exist)">Ponderosa Pine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugar_Pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugar Pine (page does not exist)">Sugar Pine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Incense-cedar" title="Incense-cedar" class="mw-redirect">Incense-cedar</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_Fir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White Fir (page does not exist)">White Fir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Douglas_Fir" title="Douglas Fir" class="mw-redirect">Douglas Fir</a>, and a few stands of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giant_Sequoia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giant Sequoia (page does not exist)">Giant Sequoia</a>, interspersed by areas of <a href="/w/index.php?title=California_Black_Oak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California Black Oak (page does not exist)">Black Oak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Live_oak" title="Live oak">Canyon Live Oak</a>. A relatively high diversity of wildlife species is supported by these habitats, because of relatively mild, lower-elevation climate and the mixture of habitat types and plant species. Wildlife species typically found in these habitats include <a href="/wiki/American_black_bear" title="American black bear">American black bear</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bobcat" title="Bobcat">Bobcat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cougar" title="Cougar">Cougar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gray_fox" title="Gray fox">Gray fox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mule_deer" title="Mule deer">Mule deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingsnake" title="Kingsnake">Mountain kingsnake</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gilbert%27s_skink" title="Gilbert's skink" class="mw-redirect">Gilbert's skink</a>, <a href="/wiki/White-headed_Woodpecker" title="White-headed Woodpecker">White-headed Woodpecker</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_Creeper" title="Brown Creeper">Brown Creeper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spotted_Owl" title="Spotted Owl">Spotted Owl</a>, and a wide variety of bat species. In the case of bats, large snags are important as roost sites.<sup id="cite_ref-wildlife_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wildlife-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Going higher in elevation, the coniferous forests become purer stands of <a href="/wiki/Fir" title="Fir">Red Fir</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_White_Pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western White Pine (page does not exist)">Western White Pine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jeffrey_Pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jeffrey Pine (page does not exist)">Jeffrey Pine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lodgepole_Pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lodgepole Pine (page does not exist)">Lodgepole Pine</a>, and the occasional <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foxtail_pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foxtail pine (page does not exist)">Foxtail pine</a>.
