Fewer wildlife species tend to be found in these habitats, because of their higher elevation and lower complexity. Species likely to be found include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden-mantled_Ground_Squirrel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel (page does not exist)">Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chickaree" title="Chickaree" class="mw-redirect">Chickaree</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fisher_(animal)" title="Fisher (animal)">Fisher</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steller%27s_Jay" title="Steller's Jay">Steller's Jay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hermit_Thrush" title="Hermit Thrush">Hermit Thrush</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Goshawk" title="Northern Goshawk">Northern Goshawk</a>. Reptiles are not common, but include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rubber_Boa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rubber Boa (page does not exist)">Rubber Boa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_fence_lizard" title="Western fence lizard">western fence lizard</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Alligator_Lizard" title="Northern Alligator Lizard">Northern Alligator Lizard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wildlife_50-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wildlife-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marmota_flaviventris_(Yellow_Bellied_Marmot),_Yosemite_NP_-_Diliff.jpg" title="File:Marmota flaviventris (Yellow Bellied Marmot), Yosemite NP - Diliff.jpg">File:Marmota flaviventris (Yellow Bellied Marmot), Yosemite NP - Diliff.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow-bellied_Marmot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow-bellied Marmot (page does not exist)">Marmot</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_Meadows" title="Tuolumne Meadows">Tuolumne Meadows</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>As the landscape rises, trees become smaller and more sparse, with stands broken by areas of exposed <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a>. These include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lodgepole_Pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lodgepole Pine (page does not exist)">Lodgepole Pine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Whitebark_Pine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Whitebark Pine (page does not exist)">Whitebark Pine</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mountain_Hemlock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mountain Hemlock (page does not exist)">Mountain Hemlock</a> that, at highest elevations, give way to vast expanses of granite as treeline is reached. The climate in these habitats is harsh and the growing season is short, but species such as <a href="/wiki/Pika" title="Pika">Pika</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow-bellied_Marmot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow-bellied Marmot (page does not exist)">Yellow-bellied Marmot</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=White-tailed_Jackrabbit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White-tailed Jackrabbit (page does not exist)">White-tailed Jackrabbit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clark%27s_Nutcracker" title="Clark's Nutcracker">Clark's Nutcracker</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Black_Rosy_Finch" title="Black Rosy Finch">Black Rosy Finch</a> are adapted to these conditions. Also, the treeless alpine habitats are the areas favored by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sierra_Nevada_Bighorn_Sheep&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sierra Nevada Bighorn Sheep (page does not exist)">Sierra Nevada Bighorn Sheep</a>. This species, however, is now found in the Yosemite area only around Tioga Pass, where a small, reintroduced population exists.<sup id="cite_ref-wildlife_50-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wildlife-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>At a variety of elevations, meadows provide important, productive habitat for wildlife. Animals come to feed on the green <a href="/wiki/Poaceae" title="Poaceae">grasses</a> and use the flowing and standing water found in many meadows. <a href="/wiki/Predation" title="Predation">Predators</a>, in turn, are attracted to these areas. The interface between meadow and forest is also favored by many animal species because of the proximity of open areas for foraging and cover for protection. Species that are highly dependent upon meadow habitat include <a href="/wiki/Great_Grey_Owl" title="Great Grey Owl">Great Grey Owl</a>, <a href="/wiki/Willow_Flycatcher" title="Willow Flycatcher">Willow Flycatcher</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_Toad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite Toad (page does not exist)">Yosemite Toad</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mountain_Beaver&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mountain Beaver (page does not exist)">Mountain Beaver</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wildlife_50-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wildlife-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Management_issues">Management issues</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:YosemiteBlackBearTagged_wb.jpg" title="File:YosemiteBlackBearTagged wb.jpg">File:YosemiteBlackBearTagged wb.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Black_Bear&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Black Bear (page does not exist)">American Black Bear</a> with a conspicuous ear tag browsing on its natural foods in Yosemite Valley</div></div></div>
<p>Despite the richness of high-quality habitats in Yosemite, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brown_Bear&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brown Bear (page does not exist)">Brown Bear</a>, <a href="/wiki/California_Condor" title="California Condor">California Condor</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Least_Bell%27s_Vireo" title="Least Bell's Vireo" class="mw-redirect">Least Bell's Vireo</a> have become <a href="/wiki/Extinct" title="Extinct" class="mw-redirect">extinct</a> in the park within historical time,<sup id="cite_ref-snepTerrestrialVertebrates_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-snepTerrestrialVertebrates-51">[51]</a></sup> and another 37 species currently have special status under either California or federal <a href="/w/index.php?title=Endangered_species&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Endangered species (page does not exist)">endangered species</a> legislation. The most serious current threats to Yosemite's wildlife and the ecosystems they occupy include loss of a natural fire regime, <a href="/wiki/Exotic_species" title="Exotic species" class="mw-redirect">exotic species</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Air_pollution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Air pollution (page does not exist)">air pollution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Habitat_fragmentation" title="Habitat fragmentation">habitat fragmentation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>. On a more local basis, factors such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Road_kill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Road kill (page does not exist)">road kills</a> and the availability of human food have affected some wildlife species.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yellow_star_thistle.jpg" title="File:Yellow star thistle.jpg">File:Yellow star thistle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Plants such as this <a href="/wiki/Centaurea_solstitialis" title="Centaurea solstitialis">Yellow Star-Thistle</a> are competing with native plants in Yosemite.</div></div></div>
<p>The black bears of Yosemite were once famous for breaking into parked cars to steal food. They were also an encouraged tourist sight for many years at the park's <a href="/wiki/Garbage_dump" title="Garbage dump" class="mw-redirect">garbage dumps</a>, where bears congregated to eat park visitors' garbage and tourists gathered to photograph the bears. Increasing encounters between bears and humans and increasing damage to property led to an aggressive campaign to discourage bears from relying on human food or interacting with people and their property. The open-air dumps were closed; all trash receptacles were replaced with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bear-resistant_food_storage_container&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bear-resistant food storage container (page does not exist)">bear-proof</a> receptacles; all campgrounds were equipped with bear-proof food lockers so that people would not leave food in their vehicles, which were easy targets for the powerful and resourceful bears. Because bears who show aggression towards people usually are eventually destroyed, park personnel have continued to come up with innovative ways to have bears associate humans and their property with unpleasant experiences, such as being hit with <a href="/wiki/Rubber_bullet" title="Rubber bullet">rubber bullets</a>. Today, about 30 bears a year are captured and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ear_tag&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ear tag (page does not exist)">ear-tagged</a> and their <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> is sampled so that, when bear damage occurs, rangers can ascertain which bear is causing the problem.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>Increasing <a href="/wiki/Ozone" title="Ozone">ozone</a> pollution is causing tissue damage to the massive <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giant_Sequoia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giant Sequoia (page does not exist)">Giant Sequoia</a> trees in the park. This makes them more vulnerable to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Insect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Insect (page does not exist)">insect</a> infestation and <a href="/wiki/Disease" title="Disease">disease</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/Conifer_cone" title="Conifer cone">cones</a> of these trees require fire-touched soil to <a href="/wiki/Germination" title="Germination">germinate</a>, historic <a href="/wiki/Wildfire#Suppression" title="Wildfire">fire suppression</a> has reduced these trees' ability to reproduce. The current policy of setting <a href="/wiki/Prescribed_fire" title="Prescribed fire" class="mw-redirect">prescribed fires</a> is expected to help the germination issue.
</p><p>Yosemite National Park has documented more than 130 non-native plant <a href="/w/index.php?title=Species&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Species (page does not exist)">species</a> within park boundaries. These non-native plants were introduced into Yosemite following the migration of early <a href="/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="European colonization of the Americas">Euro-American</a> settlers in the late 1850s. Natural and human-caused disturbances, such as wildland fires and construction activities, have contributed to a rapid increase in the spread of non-native plants. A number of these species aggressively invade and displace the native plant communities, resulting in impacts on the park's resources. Non-native plants can bring about significant changes in park ecosystems by altering the native plant communities and the processes that support them. Some non-native species may cause an increase in the fire frequency of an area or increase the available <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen">nitrogen</a> in the soil that may allow more non-native plants to become established. Many non-native species, such as <a href="/wiki/Centaurea_solstitialis" title="Centaurea solstitialis">Yellow Star Thistle</a> (<i>Centaurea solstitialis</i>), are able to produce a long <a href="/wiki/Tap_root" title="Tap root" class="mw-redirect">tap root</a> that allows them to out-compete the native plants for available water.<sup id="cite_ref-exotic_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-exotic-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bull Thistle (<i><a href="/wiki/Cirsium_vulgare" title="Cirsium vulgare">Cirsium vulgare</a></i>), Common Mullein (<i><a href="/wiki/Verbascum_thapsus" title="Verbascum thapsus">Verbascum thapsus</a></i>), and Klamath Weed (<i><a href="/wiki/Hypericum_perforatum" title="Hypericum perforatum">Hypericum perforatum</a></i>) have been identified as noxious <a href="/wiki/Pest_(organism)" title="Pest (organism)">pests</a> in Yosemite since the 1940s. Additional species that have been recognized more recently as aggressive and requiring control are Yellow Star Thistle (<i><a href="/wiki/Centaurea_solstitialis" title="Centaurea solstitialis">Centaurea solstitialis</a></i>), Sweet Clover (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Melilot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Melilot (page does not exist)">Melilot</a></i> spp.), Himalayan Blackberry (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rubus_armeniacus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rubus armeniacus (page does not exist)">Rubus armeniacus</a></i>), Cut-leaved Blackberry (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rubus_laciniatus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rubus laciniatus (page does not exist)">Rubus laciniatus</a></i>) and Large Periwinkle (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vinca_major&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vinca major (page does not exist)">Vinca major</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-exotic_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-exotic-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Activities">Activities</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yosemite_shuttlebus.jpg" title="File:Yosemite shuttlebus.jpg">File:Yosemite shuttlebus.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Yosemite <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle" title="Hybrid vehicle">Hybrid</a> Shuttle, Yosemite's free <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shuttle_bus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shuttle bus (page does not exist)">shuttle bus</a> system</div></div></div>
<p>Yosemite Valley is open year-round, but much of the remaining park is closed in late <a href="/wiki/Autumn" title="Autumn">autumn</a> because of snow and re-opens in mid to late <a href="/wiki/Spring_(season)" title="Spring (season)">spring</a>. Open-air tours around Yosemite Valley and the <a href="/wiki/Mariposa_Grove" title="Mariposa Grove">Mariposa Grove</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giant_Sequoia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giant Sequoia (page does not exist)">Giant Sequoias</a> are available. Many people enjoy short walks and longer hikes to waterfalls in Yosemite Valley, or walks amongst Giant Sequoias in the Mariposa, Tuolumne, or Merced Groves. Others like to drive or take a tour bus to <a href="/wiki/Glacier_Point" title="Glacier Point">Glacier Point</a> (summer-fall) to see a spectacular view of Yosemite Valley and the high country, or drive along the scenic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tioga_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tioga Road (page does not exist)">Tioga Road</a> to <a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_Meadows" title="Tuolumne Meadows">Tuolumne Meadows</a> (summer-fall) and go for a walk or hike.
</p><p>Most park visitors stay just for the day, and only visit locations within Yosemite Valley that are easily accessible by automobile. There is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_dollar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States dollar (page does not exist)">US$</a>20 per automobile user fee to enter the park.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">Traffic congestion</a> in the valley is a serious problem during peak season, in summer. A free <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_transport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public transport (page does not exist)">shuttle bus system</a> operates year-round in the valley, and <a href="/wiki/Park_ranger" title="Park ranger">park rangers</a> encourage people to use this system since parking within the valley during the summer is often nearly impossible to find.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to exploring the natural features of the park, visitors can also learn about the <a href="/wiki/Natural_history" title="Natural history">natural</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Culture (page does not exist)">cultural</a> history of Yosemite Valley at a number of facilities in the valley: the Yosemite Valley Visitor Center, the adjoining <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Yosemite_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yosemite Museum (page does not exist)">Yosemite Museum</a></b>, and the <b>Nature Center at Happy Isles</b>. There are also two <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmarks</a>: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=LeConte_Memorial_Lodge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LeConte Memorial Lodge (page does not exist)">LeConte Memorial Lodge</a> (Yosemite's first public visitor center), and the world-famous <a href="/wiki/Ahwahnee_Hotel" title="Ahwahnee Hotel">Ahwahnee Hotel</a>. Camp 4 was added to the <a href="/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places" title="National Register of Historic Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hiking">Hiking</span></h3>
<p>Over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of trails are available to hikers<sup id="cite_ref-naturehistory_4-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-naturehistory-4">[4]</a></sup>—anything from the easy stroll, to the grueling hikes up several park mountains, to multiple-day <a href="/wiki/Backpacking_(wilderness)" title="Backpacking (wilderness)">backpack trips</a>.
</p><p>The park can be divided into 5 sections for the day-user—Yosemite Valley, Wawona/Mariposa Grove/ Glacier Point, Tuolumne Meadows, Hetch Hetchy, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crane_Flat_Campground&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crane Flat Campground (page does not exist)">Crane Flat</a>/White Wolf. Numerous books describe park trails, and free information is available from the Park Service in Yosemite. Park rangers encourage visitors to experience portions of the park in addition to Yosemite Valley.
</p><p>Between late spring and early fall, much of the park is open to multiple-day backpack trips. All overnight trips into the back country require a wilderness permit<sup id="cite_ref-permits_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-permits-57">[57]</a></sup> and most require approved <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bear-resistant_food_storage_container&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bear-resistant food storage container (page does not exist)">bear-resistant food storage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-food_storage_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-food_storage-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Driving_destinations">Driving destinations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DanaFork.JPG" title="File:DanaFork.JPG">File:DanaFork.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Dana Fork of the <a href="/wiki/Tuolumne_River" title="Tuolumne River">Tuolumne River</a>, near the <a href="/wiki/Tioga_Pass" title="Tioga Pass">Tioga Pass</a> entrance</div></div></div>
<p>While some locations in Yosemite require hiking, other locations can be observed via automobile transportation. Driving locations also allow guests to observe the night sky in locations other than their campsite or lodge. All of the roads in Yosemite are scenic, but the most famous is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tioga_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tioga Road (page does not exist)">Tioga Road</a>, typically open from late May or early June through November.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_touring_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto_touring-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>As an alternative to driving, bicycles are allowed on the roads. However, bicycles are only allowed off-road on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of paved trails in Yosemite Valley itself; mountain biking is not allowed.<sup id="cite_ref-bike_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bike-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climbing">Climbing</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rock_climbing" title="Rock climbing">Rock climbing</a> is an important part of Yosemite.<sup id="cite_ref-climbing_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climbing-61">[61]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Camp_4_(Yosemite)" title="Camp 4 (Yosemite)">Camp 4</a>, a walk-in campground in Yosemite Valley, was instrumental in the development of rock climbing as a sport, and is listed on the <a href="/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places" title="National Register of Historic Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-camp4_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-camp4-62">[62]</a></sup> Climbers can generally be spotted in the snow-free months on anything from ten-foot-high (3&#160;m) boulders to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> face of <a href="/wiki/El_Capitan" title="El Capitan">El Capitan</a>. Classes are offered by numerous groups on rock climbing.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Winter_activities">Winter activities</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yosemite_Winter_Hiking.jpg" title="File:Yosemite Winter Hiking.jpg">File:Yosemite Winter Hiking.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A ranger-guided <a href="/wiki/Snowshoe" title="Snowshoe">snowshoe</a> walk in the park</div></div></div>
<p>Many of the roads in the park close because of heavy snow in winter; however, Yosemite Valley is open all year long. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Downhill_skiing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Downhill skiing (page does not exist)">Downhill skiing</a> is available at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Badger_Pass_Ski_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Badger Pass Ski Area (page does not exist)">Badger Pass Ski Area</a>—the oldest downhill skiing area in California, offering downhill skiing from mid-December through early April.<sup id="cite_ref-skiing_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-skiing-63">[63]</a></sup> Much of the park is open to <a href="/wiki/Cross-country_skiing" title="Cross-country skiing">cross-country skiing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snowshoe" title="Snowshoe">snowshoeing</a>, with several backcountry ski huts open for use.<sup id="cite_ref-TuolumneWinter_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TuolumneWinter-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-winter_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-winter-65">[65]</a></sup> Wilderness permits are required for backcountry overnight ski trips.<sup id="cite_ref-permits_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-permits-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bracebridge_dinner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bracebridge dinner (page does not exist)">Bracebridge dinner</a> is an annual holiday event, held since 1927 at the <a href="/wiki/Ahwahnee_Hotel" title="Ahwahnee Hotel">Ahwahnee Hotel</a>, inspired by <a href="/wiki/Washington_Irving" title="Washington Irving">Washington Irving</a>'s descriptions of Squire Bracebridge and English <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmas</a> traditions of the 18th century in his <i>Sketch Book</i>. Between 1929 and 1973, the show was organized by <a href="/wiki/Ansel_Adams" title="Ansel Adams">Ansel Adams</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bracebridge_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bracebridge-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other">Other</span></h3>
<p>Bicycle rentals are available in Yosemite Valley spring through fall. Over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of paved bike paths are available in Yosemite Valley. In addition, bicyclists can ride on regular roads. <a href="/wiki/Bicycle_helmet" title="Bicycle helmet">Helmets</a> are required by law for children under 18 years of age. Off-trail riding and <a href="/wiki/Mountain_biking" title="Mountain biking">mountain biking</a> are not permitted in Yosemite National Park.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Water activities are plentiful during warmer months. Rafting can be done through the Yosemite Valley on the Merced River. There is also a swimming pool available at Curry Village.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<p>In 2010, Yosemite National Park was honored with its own quarter under the <a href="/w/index.php?title=America_the_Beautiful_Quarters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="America the Beautiful Quarters (page does not exist)">America the Beautiful Quarters</a> program.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>

</li>
</ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<div id="section_SpokenWikipedia" class="infobox sisterproject noprint">

</p>

</td></tr>

   <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <a href="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Yosemite_National_Park" class="extiw" title="commons:Yosemite National Park">Media</a> from Commons

(page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=S:Yosemite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="S:Yosemite (page does not exist)">Source texts</a> from Wikisource



<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <a href="/wiki/File:Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg" title="File:Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg">Search Wikivoyage</a>
     <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Voy:Yosemite_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Voy:Yosemite National Park (page does not exist)">Travel guide</a> from Wikivoyage








</table>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nps.gov/yose/">National Park Service: Yosemite National Park</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.yosemiteconservancy.org/">The Yosemite Conservancy</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20100716235422/http://www.yosemite-national-park.org/">Yosemite Park Organization</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.campingatyosemite.com/">Information about camping at Yosemite National Park</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.yosemitehikes.com/hikes.htm">Yosemite Hiking Information</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://xroads.virginia.edu/~MA96/RAILROAD/home.html">The Role of the Railroads in Yellowstone and Yosemite National Parks</a> from American Studies at the University of Virginia
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Media specific
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://vimeo.com/35396305">Project Yosemite | Yosemite HD | Motion Timelapse Video</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://thehive.modbee.com/?q=node/153">Historic Yosemite Indian Chiefs – with photos</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://lib.byu.edu/digital/irvine/">Historic Photographs of Yosemite National Park taken by Edith Irvine</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.yosemite-17-gigapixels.com/">Zoomable 17 Gigapixel images of Yosemite</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://projectyose.com/">Project Yosemite | An ongoing adventure to timelapse Yosemite in an extreme way</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.archive.org/details/my_first_summer_in_the_sierra_ap_0906_librivox/">My First Summer in the Sierra</a> by John Muir. Free MP3 audio recording from LibriVox.org
</li>
</ul>
